item.title: Ukrainian Soldiers Trade Tanks and Artillery on the Front Line
item.description: Most of the bartering involves items captured from Russian troops, which are exchanged for urgently needed supplies. “Let’s just call it a simplification of bureaucracy,” one soldier said.
item.media:description: Repairing a captured Russian armored personnel carrier in the Donetsk region of Ukraine last week.

item.title: Death in Navy SEAL Training Exposes a Culture of Brutality, Cheating and Drugs
item.description: The elite force’s selection course is so punishing that few make it through, and many of those who do resort to illicit tactics.
item.dc:creator: Dave Philipps
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Response to Trump Search Highlights Violent Rhetoric From the Right
item.description: As they did before the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, the former president and his allies are fueling outrage among supporters.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has often sought to demonize his adversaries.

item.title: Trump Hires Christopher Kise as Lawyer in Mar-a-Lago Documents Case
item.description: The former president has brought Christopher M. Kise onto his legal team after struggling to find high-profile lawyers willing to work for him on the investigation into his handling of classified material.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Christopher M. Kise, seen in 2005, is the former solicitor general of Florida.

item.title: Mississippi Governor Declares Emergency Over Drinking Water Crisis
item.description: In Jackson, residents have long contended with boil-water notices and service disruptions. But now, officials say, the system has been pushed to the brink.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas

item.title: Thousands in Michigan Without Power After Midwest Storms Kill 3
item.description: A line of storms produced wind gusts from 60 to 80 miles per hour in some areas and knocked out power to thousands of customers in Michigan and Indiana.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina and Christine Hauser
item.media:description: A tree in the road in Spring Arbor, Mich. Severe thunderstorms caused widespread power outages.

item.title: Jonathan Majors Is More Than a Marvel Supervillain
item.description: Inside​ ​the​ ​captivating​ ​mind​ ​of​ ​a new Hollywood star.
item.dc:creator: Rowan Ricardo Phillips
item.media:credit: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

item.title: This Remote Mine Could Foretell the Future of America’s Electric Car Industry
item.description: Hiding a thousand feet below the earth’s surface in this patch of northern Minnesota wetlands are ancient mineral deposits that some view as critical to fueling America’s clean energy future.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Tim Gruber
item.media:credit: Tim Gruber for The New York Times

item.title: Serena Williams Rises to the Occasion, Like So Many Times Before
item.description: Williams met a valedictory night at the U.S. Open with a win that was fitting, and with a second-round match on Wednesday, the farewell party at Arthur Ashe Stadium continues.
item.dc:creator: Christopher Clarey
item.media:credit: Michelle V. Agins/The New York Times
item.media:description: Serena Williams celebrating her win over Danka Kovinic on Monday night.

item.title: Serena Williams Fans Flock to the First Match of Her Final US Open
item.description: A star-studded crowd inside Arthur Ashe Stadium was joined by throngs of fans outside during Williams’s first-round U.S. Open match.
item.dc:creator: David Waldstein
item.media:description: Fans cheered for Serena Williams of the United States after she won a point against Danka Kovinic of Montenegro. The night session Monday set an attendance record.

item.title: In Brazil, the Last Member of an Isolated Indigenous Tribe Dies
item.description: Known as the “Man of the Hole,” the last member of an Indigenous group was found dead this month, marking the first recorded disappearance of an isolated tribe in the country.
item.dc:creator: Flávia Milhorance and André Spigariol
item.media:description: A still image from a video provided by the Brazilian government showing one of the huts built by the “Man of the Hole” in Rondônia State in 2018.

item.title: Washington Post’s Business Struggles as Frustrations Mount
item.description: With digital subscriptions and digital advertising revenue stagnating, the company is on a pace to lose money this year.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
item.media:description: Fred Ryan, the chief executive and publisher of The Washington Post, with Sally Buzbee, the executive editor, left.

item.title: After Clashes Kill 24, Iraq Cleric Works to Defuse Tension in Baghdad
item.description: With no functioning government and no common ground, tensions among Shiite political factions have become a deadly matter in Baghdad this week.
item.dc:creator: Jane Arraf
item.media:description: Fighters from a group linked with the Shiite cleric Muqtada al-Sadr clashed with Iraqi security forces, including members of Iran-backed militias, in Baghdad on Tuesday.

item.title: How ‘the Most Vicious, Horrible Animal Alive’ Became a YouTube Star
item.description: Joseph Carter, known to his online followers as the Mink Man, trains feisty carnivores to rid canals and urban river banks of midsize pests.
item.dc:creator: Oliver Whang and Kim Raff
item.media:credit: Kim Raff for The New York Times

item.title: Why I Changed My Mind on Student Debt Forgiveness
item.description: Our current system of student loans and college funding is at odds with what we hope to achieve by encouraging people to go to college.
item.dc:creator: Susan Dynarski
item.media:credit: Illustration by Sam Whitney/The New York Times; image by Nay Ni Ratn Mak Can Thuk/EyeEm, via Getty Images

item.title: Why Anthony Fauci’s Covid Legacy Is a Failure
item.description: A science worth following must lead.
item.dc:creator: Ari Schulman
item.media:credit: Illustration by Zisiga Mukulu/The New York Times; photograph by Doug Mills/The New York Times

item.title: Bill Barr Made the Decision to Clear Trump, and That Should Still Frighten Us
item.description: The ability to investigate future high-level wrongdoing in the executive branch is at stake.
item.dc:creator: Neal K. Katyal
item.media:description: Donald Trump and Attorney General Bill Barr in 2019.

item.title: Ted Cruz Would Like to Put Some Words in Your Mouth
item.description: The idea that student loan relief is a handout to a small minority of affluent college graduates is simply a myth.
item.dc:creator: Jamelle Bouie
item.media:credit: Travis Dove for The New York Times

item.title: I’m a Ukrainian Soldier, and I’ve Accepted My Death
item.description: So it must be for those who tread the path of war.
item.dc:creator: Artem Chekh
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: A mass burial in Bucha, Ukraine, this month.

item.title: What It’s Like to Have Face Blindness
item.description: When you can’t rely on facial recognition, you look beyond the obvious.
item.dc:creator: James Robinson

item.title: Europe’s Gonna Party Like It’s 1979
item.description: Sometimes you just can’t let markets rip.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman

item.title: The Book That Explains Our Cultural Stagnation
item.description: Art has gotten so boring. W. David Marx knows why.
item.dc:creator: Michelle Goldberg
item.category: Status and Culture: How Our Desire for Social Rank Creates Taste, Identity, Art, Fashion, and Constant Change (Book)
item.media:credit: Calla Kessler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Partygoers at Art Basel Miami Beach.

item.title: A Poorer Generation
item.description: Americans under 40 have had to cope with a worse economy than earlier generations. How should it affect the debate over Biden’s debt-relief plan?
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:description: Student loan forgiveness advocates attend a press conference in front of the White House in Washington, DC, last week.

item.title: Inside the Adolescent Mental Health Crisis
item.description: Young people in the United States are facing a new set of risks. Why has the situation caught so many people off guard?
item.dc:creator: Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Rikki Novetsky, Stella Tan, Patricia Willens, Mike Benoist, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
item.media:credit: Annie Flanagan for The New York Times
item.media:description: C started experiencing feelings of restlessness, depressions and anxiety as early as the third grade.

item.title: Introducing ‘The Run-Up,’ a Politics Podcast from The New York Times
item.description: The midterm elections are usually a referendum on the party in power. This year, they’re about so much more.

item.title: How Will the Student Loan Forgiveness Plan Affect You?
item.description: We want to hear about what President Biden’s debt cancellation plan means for your life and finances.
item.dc:creator: Lora Kelley
item.media:credit: Kendrick Brinson for The New York Times

item.title: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Deaths Among Older People, Israeli Study Finds
item.description: Among patients under 65, however, the drug made little difference in hospitalization or death rates.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin
item.media:description: According to the new Israeli study, the medication was highly effective when administered to individuals 65 and over.

item.title: Scenes from the Devastating Flooding in Pakistan
item.description: Months of rain has swollen rivers and inundated communities across Pakistan, killing more than 1,000 people.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times

item.title: Lisa LaFlamme Ouster Sets Off Outcry in Canada
item.description: The chief executive of a Canadian news network pushed back against allegations that sex, age or gray hair were factors in the abrupt dismissal of the veteran journalist, Lisa LaFlamme.
item.dc:creator: Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: Lisa LaFlamme after winning a Best News Anchor award in April.

item.title: More Children Are Swallowing Batteries and Landing in the E.R.
item.description: Twice as many kids needed treatment after putting button batteries in their mouths, noses and ears compared with the previous decade, a new study says. Here’s how to prevent it, and what to do if it happens.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Pearson

item.title: Why Chosen Families are Important for L.G.B.T.Q. People
item.description: For L.G.B.T.Q. people, the bonds between friends can be liberating and transformative. Five of these close-knit communities tell their stories.
item.dc:creator: Dani Blum

item.title: Covid Vaccines for Kids Are Dividing Divorced Parents
item.description: For some parents who share custody, the Covid vaccine has created a minefield of issues that initial divorce decrees could not have anticipated.
item.dc:creator: Debra Kamin

item.title: Feeling Ambivalent About Motherhood Is Normal
item.description: After years of engaging with parenthood from a distance, it’s time for a psychiatrist specializing in women’s mental health to take her own advice.
item.dc:creator: Pooja Lakshmin, M.D.

item.title: Kids Are Using Social Media More Than Ever, Study Finds
item.description: The report highlights a 17 percent increase in screen use among teens and tweens in the last two years — more than in the four years prior.
item.dc:creator: Melinda Wenner Moyer
item.media:credit: Dmitry Kostyukov for The New York Times

item.title: Exploring Spain’s Arab Influence
item.description: Exploring the country’s Arab influence is an impossibly romantic journey, involving palaces with intricate geometric designs, castles and grand mosques reconfigured by Christians into cathedrals.
item.dc:creator: Nina Burleigh
item.category: United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organization
item.media:credit: Emilio Parra Doiztua for The New York Times
item.media:description: Córdoba’s Mosque-Cathedral, or La Mezquita, was one of the first and grandest mosques in Europe.
